So you want to travel and live in another country, but your bank account is ruining your plans? Consider working in another country. Companies are worldwide, and possibilities can be found anywhere! It’s not just about teaching. There are many different types of jobs and industries to choose from, so there is always a method to work overseas. It’s never too late to make working abroad work for you, whether you’re looking for methods to work abroad after college, making a mid-career transition, or seeking employment abroad for over 50s.

Working abroad can refer to a variety of activities. Working abroad is a procedure that varies depending on where you travel, who you work for, and how long you expect to stay. It’s critical to consider all of the specifics before deciding on the best strategy to work overseas. But don’t worry, we’ve got you covered!

Age considerations 

In most cases, age is just a number, but when it comes to working abroad, it can limit your options. The first rule of working overseas is that you will always require a visa. Your visa, second only to your passport, is the key to lawfully working and living in the nation of your choice. This is when your age comes into play.

Yes, there are occupations for those over 50 in other countries. Even if you don’t qualify for a working holiday visa, there is still employment available beyond 50. Whether you choose to continue your job in a different nation, take a career sabbatical, or volunteer throughout your retirement years, remember that you have options.

When it comes to living your dream life overseas, your age will not be a barrier to your success. It’s simply that your route there isn’t the same as everyone else’s.

1. Through a service provider/agency

Regardless of where they are headquartered, program providers provide a diverse choice of employment, internship, and volunteer abroad options all around the world. From the moment you express interest to the time you return home, services like these are there to assist you to sort out everything you did and didn’t think about. You can get assistance with your visa, phone, and job placement, among other things, for a charge that varies from agency to agency. It’s one of the greatest methods to work overseas if you find yourself in need of a little extra motivation or organization.

Pros: These people are here to make your move to a new country as painless as possible. They’ll assist you with obtaining your visa, driver’s license, and health insurance, as well as setting up an overseas bank account if necessary.

Cons: Depending on the level of assistance you require, these agencies’ costs might be quite substantial. You’ll have less money to spend when you arrive. Budgeting ahead of time, on the other hand, can turn this major disadvantage into a minor one.

2. Work as a teacher in another country.

Because you feel that children are the future, you should educate them well and lead by example as a teacher in another country. With a TEFL certification, you may teach practically anywhere in the world and leave a lasting impression on your pupils. Teach pupils English while also learning a little bit of the local tongue. You will work flexible hours and, thanks to your earnings, will have time to travel around your selected country. It’s work abroad option that anyone, young or old, experienced or not, can take advantage of. The only criterion for this employment is that you speak English fluently. Isn’t that pretty?

Pros: While it’s never about the money, your teaching salary mixed with the country’s low cost of living is a huge plus! While you can put it aside for your own vacations, the money you have leftover can be used to pay off your school loans. (Extremely skilled!)

Cons: While culture shock is only temporary, it is quite real and will undoubtedly be a hardship when it comes to adjusting to your new life abroad.

3. Move to another country, then find work

For all of you adventurers out there! You don’t necessarily need a job to get where you want to go. If you have the ability to get up and go, take advantage of it. Don’t let others make you second-guess your choices; just because your choice is unconventional doesn’t imply it’s doomed. If you go this method, you’ll need our well-organized checklist, which will help your relocation go more smoothly. Apply for jobs before you arrive, network with recruiters, and get started right away.

Pros: You are in charge of your own destiny. Being entirely self-sufficient is a proven way to immerse yourself in your new country’s culture while still having complete control over your experience.

Cons: Moving overseas in this manner is equivalent to taking up a second full-time career. It will be difficult to begin your life, especially given the amount of paperwork you would have to deal with.

4. Obtain a visa for a working holiday.

Securing a working holiday visa is a wonderful choice if you don’t wish to work overseas permanently. Travelers between the ages of 18 and 35 are eligible and depending on the country they visit, they can stay for up to two years. While your working holiday visa dictates where you can legally work and live for a period of time, it does not limit you from doing any free travel.

Pros: Having work experience on your resume is one of the best things about a working holiday visa. When you return home and begin searching for jobs, your time abroad will stand out as a unique experience that will set you apart from other candidates.

Cons: There is an age restriction. While other visas aren’t as simple to come by as working vacation visas, there are still ways to work overseas after the age of 35.

5. Participate in a work swap

Completing a work exchange is the closest you can get to traveling overseas for free if you’re on a tight budget. You may do a variety of things through a labor exchange from almost anywhere in the world. In Israel, you may be a video production intern, in Bali, a marketing intern, or in Argentina, you could work in a hostel. All you have to worry about is getting a visa because you work in exchange for your room and board! So, if you want to travel without breaking the bank, a job exchange is the way to go.

Pros: You will be provided with free housing and, depending on the program, free food. It’s a tremendous relief to not have to worry about food or where you’ll stay. The only budgeting you’ll have to deal with will be for your personal excursions.

Cons: While your lodging will be provided free of charge for the duration of the program, you will have no control over where you stay. Most of the time, your lodgings will not be as luxurious as you are accustomed to at home.

6. Become a volunteer

The act of giving back isn’t limited to your local neighborhood. Take your passion for a cause and utilize it to benefit people all around the world. You get to be a part of something important and meaningful in addition to traveling. As a volunteer, you won’t get paid for your job, but the time you spend helping communities, solving problems, and learning cross-cultural communication will be worth far more than any income you’ll receive. Volunteering is undoubtedly one of the finest methods to work overseas after college because there is so much you can gain from it.

Pros: Volunteering abroad allows you to properly understand the world around you. A destination is more than just a brochure for tourists or a guide for visitors. Outside of the tourist bubble, get to know the residents, their culture, and their language.

Cons: Issues do not magically resolve themselves. As a result, be prepared for the terrible reality that you won’t be able to assist everyone. While your efforts will always be valued, true transformation takes time and can be a difficult journey in and of itself.

7. Freelancer

As a digital nomad, you can work as a travel writer, a web designer, a photographer, or a vlogger, among other things. While exploring the world, earn money and expand your client base. If you can’t imagine working 9 to 5 in a cramped cubicle, becoming a digital nomad is one of the finest ways to work overseas while pursuing your passions. This way of living is perfect for self-employed people who want to have a flexible schedule.

Pros: Working as a digital nomad allows you to choose your own hours and be your own boss! Taking control of your profession is a significant statement to make, and one you should be proud of!

Cons: The downside to this lifestyle is that your income will fluctuate. Before you go to become a digital nomad, make sure you have enough money in the bank to cover the days when you won’t be working.
